perturbation.explanation: By changing 'shall maintain adequate books and records' to 'may maintain books and records' and 'shall include' to 'may include', the agreement weakens the requirement for proper accounting practices. This introduces a legal contradiction, especially regarding tax obligations and potential liability issues. In Pennsylvania, businesses are legally required to maintain accurate records for tax purposes and to ensure transparency and accountability. The original clause mandates adherence to generally accepted accounting principles and regular financial reporting, which are essential for legal compliance. By weakening the language, the altered clause creates a loophole that could be exploited to avoid legal and financial responsibilities, therefore failing to comply with state laws regarding business accounting practices and financial transparency.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania state laws regarding business accounting practices and financial transparency.

perturbation.original_text:
If requested
by a Joint Venturer, the Joint Venture books and records shall be audited
as of the close of each year by an independent accountant acceptable to
both Joint Venturers. All books and records of every kind and character, of
the Joint Venture, and other information, shall be kept at the principal
office of the Joint Venture, or at such other place or places as may be
agreed upon by the Joint Venturers, and shall be fully available to each
Joint Venturer or his duly authorized representative, all at reasonable
times. The books of the Joint Venture shall represent the complete record
and report of business operations, including a balance sheet and income and
expense statements reflecting all receipts and disbursements of the Joint
Venture, and such reports shall be submitted to the Joint Venturers on a
regular basis.
perturbation.changed_text:
If requested
by a Joint Venturer, the Joint Venture books and records may be audited.
All books and records of every kind and character, of
the Joint Venture, and other information, may be kept at a location
agreed upon by the Joint Venturers, and shall be available to each
Joint Venturer or his representative. The books of the Joint Venture shall represent a record
of business operations.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause mandating that books and records 'shall be kept at the principal office of the Joint Venture' and changing 'shall be' audited to 'may be audited' introduces a significant legal risk. Pennsylvania law requires businesses to maintain accurate financial records and make them accessible for audits and legal proceedings. By allowing the records to be kept at any agreed-upon location, and removing the requirement for regular submission of reports, the contract hinders transparency and compliance with legal requirements for financial accountability. The modification also omits the requirement for an independent accountant acceptable to both parties and the requirements for reports of operation and financial statements, further hindering legal transparency.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania business regulations regarding financial record-keeping and auditing.

perturbation.original_text:
On any termination of the Joint
Venture, its debt shall be paid or provided for in a manner satisfactory to
the Joint Venturers. Then, any unexpended portion of Joint Venture funds
shall be distributed to the Joint Venturers in accordance with their
prorata ownership in the Joint Venture and all other assets of the Joint
Venture shall be distributed as undivided interests to the Joint Venturers
ratably according to their prorata interests in the Joint Venture as set
forth in Section 6. If any asset is not capable of being distributed on an
undivided basis, the Parties shall agree on a price for such asset and it
shall be distributed to one Party and a corresponding balance, in cash or
property, shall be made of the Joint Venture assets so that each Party
receives his proportionate share of all the Joint Venture assets.
perturbation.changed_text:
On any termination of the Joint
Venture, its debt will be addressed. Then, any unexpended portion of Joint Venture funds
will be distributed to the Joint Venturers. If any asset is not capable of being distributed, the Parties shall agree on a price for such asset and it
shall be distributed to one Party.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting the specific requirement that debts 'shall be paid or provided for in a manner satisfactory to the Joint Venturers', and removing 'in accordance with their prorata ownership in the Joint Venture and all other assets of the Joint Venture shall be distributed as undivided interests to the Joint Venturers ratably according to their prorata interests in the Joint Venture as set forth in Section 6' from the section, the contract removes legal safeguards for equitable distribution of assets and debt resolution upon termination. This creates a contradiction with Pennsylvania's partnership laws, which mandate fair and proportional distribution of assets and liabilities based on ownership percentages to protect the rights of all parties involved. The omission introduces potential for disputes and non-compliance with legal standards for winding up a business venture.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania partnership laws regarding asset distribution and debt resolution upon termination of a business venture.
